Award.AwardTitle: Precision, Accuracy, and Aliasing of Sea Ice Thickness from Multiple Observing Platforms
Award.AbstractNarration: Much attention on the extent, and changes therein, of Arctic sea ice focuses on areal coverage. Equally if not more important to consider is the thickness of the ice, which varies with age and also due to movement of the ice. Thickness is geometrically rough with ridges, rubble fields, and open-water leads. These features are asymmetrically shaped from centimeters to meters in one horizontal direction and meters to kilometers along the other. Instruments used to sense ice thickness typically have wide footprints that alias these rough features into smoother flatter features. Accurate thickness distribution of these deformed areas is needed to reduce uncertainties in global thickness data archives. Such results lead to higher accuracy in regional and global sea ice volume estimates. High precision and consistency from a single instrument cannot quantify the impact of aliasing. The sea ice community currently seeks an integrated- instrument approach to measure sea ice thickness from its components of draft, freeboard, and surface elevation (including snow loads) and thickness archives are being developed. This project would address the central question, "What is the impact of spatial aliasing when measuring sea ice thickness, its distribution, and resulting volume?" The approach is to work with datasets that include measurements made by two or more instruments with different footprints in the same location, based on a recently discovered relationship between the roughness of 5m and 40m footprints stemming from one field experiment. Using this dataset a valid correction (to better than 10 cm) was found using the roughness ratio between the two measurements. The investigator proposes that this type of relationship can be generalized for all types of sea ice thickness measurements. The investigator will organize and archive climate data records containing coincident sea ice thickness measurements from instruments of different footprints and incorporate these data with existing sea ice thickness archives. The main scientific contribution will be an improved metadata relationship to characterize properties that contribute to thickness uncertainties in climate data archive records. A Ph.D. thesis will advance the aliasing hypothesis using airborne electromagnetic (EM) measurements to devise a correction by leveraging the accompanying high-resolution laser altimeter already integrated into the EM technology. The broader impacts of the work include the improved thickness archive and the training of a Ph.D. student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF funded project ARC-1107725 is concluding with the following outcomes.


1) Five peer-reviewed publications and one outreach publication

2) Active participation in data portal set up through the Arctic Collaboration Environment (ACE). ACE lead is now head of the IARPC Data Management (Joe Casas) at https://ace.arsc.edu/ wherein several of our field work photos and data are integrated into a Google-Earth driven collaborative archive.

3) A data archive of Barrow 2013 field exercises for students. Joint effort between US Naval Academy, University of Washington, and University of Delaware (UD) including sea ice thickness data sets from UD with uncertainties for each variable and associated metadata. https://ace.arsc.edu/content/naicex with final version including calibration to be archived with ACADIS by December 2015 following completion of Doctoral Student Related Thesis.

4) Student apprenticeship program launched at UD for sea ice training (http://sites.udel.edu/merlinproject/)

5) Four Student Degrees/Mentoring. Three Ph.D. students and one Master’s student (see full report for list and thesis topics under products.

6) Three outreach films explaining Local-to-Polar Connections between the Arctic and New England/Mid-Atlantic States and 29 scientific/public talks in VT, NH, NY, DE, CT, Hobart Australia. See full report for list under products.

7) Forthcoming products based on the completion and defense of Ph.D. thesis by J. P. Samluk (estimated Dec 2015) include four more publications and scientific quality data archive to reproduce findings in the four papers named above; submitted to ACADIS with error, quality assurance parameters, and images/videos. An open-source Python version of co-calibration between EM instruments of different footprint sizes is also being considered pending technology transfer funding pursuits.

8) Impacts in four major areas of Research, Education, Logistics/Safety, and Outreach/Communication. See full report for detailed listing.
